title: 107_hr4626
content: The Act titled "Encouraging Work and Supporting Marriage Act of 2002" accelerates marriage penalty relief by increasing the standard deduction for joint returns in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act "Encouraging Work and Supporting Marriage Act of 2002" accelerates marriage penalty relief by adjusting the applicable percentage for taxable years starting in 2003 or later. The standard deduction for joint returns is increased, and an amendment changes the effective date to apply after December 31, 2002. SEC. 201. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding eligibility of ex-felons, increasing the maximum age for food stamp recipients, and clarifying treatment of individuals under individual work plans. The amendments made by this section apply to individuals who start work for the employer after December 31, 2002. SEC. 202. Consolidation of Work Opportunity Credit with Welfare-to-Work Credit applies to individuals starting work after December 31, 2002. The text discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding long-term family assistance recipients. It defines the term and outlines the certification process by the designated local agency. The text discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding long-term family assistance recipients. It defines the term and outlines the certification process by the designated local agency. The eligibility criteria include being a member of a family receiving assistance for a specified period and having a hiring date within two years of the end of that period. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to provide increased credit for the employment of long-term family assistance recipients. This includes a credit for second-year wages for such recipients, with 40 percent of qualified second-year wages being included in the work opportunity credit for the taxable year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to provide increased credit for the employment of long-term family assistance recipients. The credit for second-year wages for such recipients shall not exceed $10,000 per year and includes qualified wages paid during a specific 1-year period. Special rules apply for agricultural and railway labor employees. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the credit for employing long-term family assistance recipients. The credit for second-year wages is now $10,000 per year, with special rules for agricultural and railway labor employees. Section 51A is repealed, and the amendments apply to individuals starting work after December 31, 2002. Passed the House of Representatives on May 21, 2002.
